Obviously a lot of attention has been put into the design of this place. The pour-over bar is a large white table with electric scales built into it to closely monitor the brewing process. 
I'm not sure if this was the usual procedure for brewing coffee, but it appears that the water was heated by filling the small pour-over pitcher with water, then heating it on a hot-pad type burner with an electric thermometer in it. 
This is obviously more time consuming than using the modern hot water machines that other modern coffee shops use, but ok - maybe this is somehow more authentic.
The problem was when our barista hit some sort of technical problem while brewing cup 2 of 2 (perhaps accidentally using 2 filters?). This led to that cup being aborted halfway through and the whole process starting over from the beginning, including boiling the water.
This took an incredibly long time. Meanwhile the other barista was putting out espresso based drinks at a conventional pace to the other customers crowding the small shop. 
I was not in a hurry. I'm very interested in the technique and the equipment and the process and all that stuff. But holy cow. This probably took about 25 minutes. I can't imagine trying to convince conventional coffee consumers this was somehow better than what they are used to. or convince coffee aficionados that this is somehow better than making pour-over coffee using a chemex pot or hario v60 cones. 
The coffee was ok. Pretty good light/medium roast third-wave style fresh, quality single origin coffee that many have become familiar with in this day and age.

The single best thing about this place was that they offered a pour over decaf that was delicious. This was the cup they got right at the beginning. A+ on that one. 

the people working there were nice enough.
I now understand that the various coffee beans are sold in different size bags so that they are around the same price point. 16oz is too big of a commitment for me though.
author: RK W.

description: So one of the main reasons I wanted to check this place out is because I saw a post by my favorite blogger that was shot here. The coffee was good but nothing overly special. Honestly the coolest part about this place was the science behind the pour over and the pineapple wallpaper!
author: Teresa C.

description:
Really good coffee for purchase to take home and brew. High quality and varieties you won't find anywhere else. 

Also serves up a great cup of Joe or a Latte. Good if you want to grab a drink and run.

Would be 5 stars if had a little more room to hang out, but then again it's not really the hanging out kind of coffee place. Clean and modern feel inside. It's like a Japanese/Italian fusion coffee shop. 

You come here to get really good coffee, not work on your PowerPoint slides. 

Super nice staff
author: auclair k.

description: Amazing product and fantastic ambiance. All of the employees are engaging and have great insight to their processes. 100% a place you should hit up for some fire Java.
author: Drew W.

description: Totally loved this place. Get the savory scone - yum! The latte tasted and looked great with pretty foam art. The bathroom is huge and the service was friendly. What more can you ask for? A+
author: Noelle F.

description: The coffee here is sooo good. Honestly, the best coffee I've had. They have soy and almond milk as dairy free options. Coffee is made fresh to order. And they have an array of treats although I passed on the opportunity to try them. The seating is a bit challenging. They have seating along the wall of their pineapple wall paper (which is so cute), and some at the barista area. There's a few tables outside, but otherwise its better to just get your coffee and go.
author: Nathalie N.

description: Very hip little spot with nice service and good pour-over.
author: Glenn M.

description: Best espresso in the whole City. Fell in love with the pineapple'd space. Ambiance and espresso passion made for the loveliest 30 min find in the City in along time. So glad to have spotted this little yet glamorous espresso gem...my new zen spot in all the hustle-bustle :)
author: Tricia W.

description: Cute, small, boutique coffee shop. The pineapple wallpaper an bleak white counter top and seating areas make it very hipster and feminine. Pour over coffee was $5.  It was a huge cup, but damn! I enjoyed sitting outside and soaking in the nice weather with my girlfriend.
author: Elise G.

description: I signed up for Wrecking Ball's roasted coffee subscription on Membo, and I couldn't be happier!!  A new blend is delivered to my door every month -- it allows me to try a lot of different roasts.  I haven't checked out their location, but I heard it's a cute spot in Cow Hollow.  I recommend everyone check out Wrecking Ball (I can't wait to brew it in the morning.  It smells and tastes divine). I think it's better than Blue Bottle. (sorry)  I was not aware of Wrecking Ball until I found their coffee subscription on Membo (joinmembo.com).
author: Kathy M.

description: Super clean and modern boutique coffee shop. You cant really get work done here due to space, but I love this little shop. Will be back!
author: Mike C.

description:
Hottest in the game right now. It's your no frills bar, churning some serious smiles, Michelin style customer service, and eye-opening coffee brewing. I happened to be in SF for the week and on my first visit got lucky to have the one and only Nick Cho pulling shots like a baws. Result? Best espresso I've ever had. And I'm no typical newb strolling in from soul cycle.  Had to come back in on 3 consecutive days to chase that first high. 

Fetco is dialed in properly but if you want a personalized touch of delicacy and intricacy, get a pour over (using kalita 155)

I've been to some of the best coffee spots throughout America and can easily say this is the best coffee you'll get in this country. The world? haven't traveled enough.
author: Wejjy S.

description: Really good coffee in a great neighborhood. No crazy menu here with 100's of different drinks. Just the basics done really well. Not a lot of seating inside so if that's what you are looking for and it's busy then be prepared to stand.
author: Christopher B.

description: Absolutely fantastic. Best cappuccino I've ever had, and the service was impeccable. Fun pineapple wallpaper lines the wall and the small setting makes for a personable experience. I will absolutely be returning here again.
author: Mallory W.

description: Great crew, super friendly serving excellent coffee. I had the flat white and it was GREAT. The pastry recommendation from the barista was on point. I had the cheese spinach turnover and it was also super yum yum. Very solid, simply purist coffee spot. Thank you Wrecking Ball y'all's my people.
author: Josh Q.

description: Great new addition to Union Street. Fantastic bean selection. My partner had a great pour over that was rich and fragrant. I ordered the mocha that was absolutely decadent. Definitely worth a stop.
author: Victoria O.

description: Great coffee, stopped by randomly today while walking around on Union st. This place is where That Takes The Cake cupcake shop used to be and I'm happy to see that it turns into a cute little coffee shop. Had the ethiopian iced coffee, it's clean and slightly fruity w/o too much acidity. Very smooth and easy to drink on a warm sunny afternoon in SF. Will definitely return to try their pour over next time I am around!
author: Joyce C.

description: Coffe was really yummy! They had cool wallpaper which made it more fun to sit and talk with friends.
author: Page F.

description: They are doing it right. The antithesis of the dark roast, wood + steel shops all over town. They are focused on lighter roasts. The shop is extremely clean and bright. Delicious coffee, limited seating.
author: Ben S.

description: Excellent cappuccino, very friendly staff, and a unique space. Quality on par with Blue Bottle et al without the crazy waits.
author: Ryan C.

description: I really want to like this place (and I love the vibe and the barista was super friendly) but their coffee is just so-so and really expensive.
author: G W.

description:
Excellent coffee and great service. Wrecking ball is my favorite local spot.

Pros: great drip & espresso based drinks, lovely fruit Danish. Never a long wait.

Cons: Small storefront
author: Guy V.

description: This review is about online ordering. There was a hiccup between the time when I ordered and it was sent; however,  when all was said and done,  Matt, the roaster, contacted me to ensure my order had been handled,  and to not only make it right for me,  but also to ensure their system worked properly in the future. In my conversation with him,  it was clear that he had a genuine interest in improving customer service at wrecking ball, and ensuring online ordering will be as positive of an experience as going to the cafe is.  Which from what I hear is pretty great.
author: Stewart C.

description: These people know how to really make coffee. Run by leading experts in coffee. However if you're not a coffee drinker, try the hot chocolate. It is beyond amazing as well.
author: Christina C.

description: You can find hundreds of hip coffee shops in SF these days but contrarily to many, the owner of Wrecking Ball will make you feel welcome & appreciated. And that's in addition to coffee being prepared with care & tasting just as great. They sell Marla buns (pastries with hints of cardamon & other spices), and these are a coffee's best friend!
author: Laure W.

description: If you are a coffee connoisseur, this is your place. The beans are amazing. The latte's and cappuccino made in the French and Italian styles. Best spot in SF--located on the quiet block of Union Street; close to Rose's Cafe. I loved Blue Bottle until I discovered Wrecking Ball. When a coffee spot scales, they lose something (flavor, beans? no idea--but coffee not the same). We now order all our coffee beans from here and are just thrilled....
author: Margaret B.

description: Independent of its price, they deserve 5 stars because the coffee is good , but come on 3$ for a coffee which is not individually made( like philz ) . It is expensive
author: Alireza R.

description: In a city with micro roasters growing too quickly and loosing their quality - these guys still understand what artisanal means. Best cortado in the city.
author: Karim T.

description: Stopped in here to try the hot chocolate. I had heard they use TCHO so I was pretty excited to see what their drink is like. TCHO did not disappoint. My first sip was stunningly delightful, a very rich and delicious drink. I was a little bummed that they don't do the hot coco with almond milk because it is pre-made with dairy. The extreme creaminess, while amazing at first, got to be a little too much by my last sip. I was glad it came in an 8oz rather than 12. As for atmosphere: the staff was friendly and informative, the space is small, welcoming, and quiet so plenty of space to sit.
author: Jaedra D.

description: Their pillowfight espresso blend is the best coffee's I have had (so far atleast) in all of the Bay Area and Chicago combined. I bought myself a bag of these, and while my french press brew of it tastes good, it cannot be compared with the one they brew here. I drive all the way from Cole Valley to here on weekends just to get this coffee.
author: Hari N.

description: Delicious lattes and friendly staff. The tables outside could be cleared more rapidly, but otherwise a great experience.
author: Erik L.

description: The coffee is good, but not as good as at Union Street Coffee Roastery just up the street at Union and Fillmore. The "service" though really stinks. There is too much pretentiousness and not enough caring about customers there.
author: Lars J.

description: Top marks for the product. Well poured, quality coffee, especially their cappuccinos. The space is cramped so it's not suitable if you want to linger. The staff are a moody bunch so don't expect a lot of sunny chit-chat.
author: 1 D.

description: coffee is good, staff is awesome and they carry compartes candy bars. they cost 10$ but they're worth it. this is one of my new favorite places in SF.
author: Anthony A.

description: Amazing coffee and great crew working there.  The blends are something I look forward too and it says a lot that I am willing to drive with a cup in my hand from there to the Financial District.  I am coffee lover and these guys hit the spot.
author: mike s.

description: Their capps are Michael Jackson smooth. These people know what they're doing! Go go go.
author: A G.

description: By far and away the BEST mocha I have enjoyed in this city and I have been hunting pretty hard. They are meticulous. The chocolate is heated in a water bath with a sous vide machine then it's weighed on a scale for the precise amount every time. The foam is perfection. Flavor is spot on. Exactly what I was looking for. I will go majorly out of my way to come here.
author: Alexa S.

description: great cup of joe, seriously.  staff is friendly, their setup is high tech and the beans are roasted beautifully.  love the quaint little shop, definitely not your pretentious ritual or four barrel.  much better coffee though.  easily missable, but look for the logo and coffee.  best coffee in the neighborhood by far, up there in the top 3 of sf.
author: shar d.
